title: #301 What the Like Button Tells You About Your Customers | Bob Goodson, Inventor of the Like Button

rawLines.text: Welcome to dataf framed. This is Richie.
The like button is a ubiquitous feature
of social media messaging and content
platforms. It's such a simple user
interface feature, but one that
generates a powerful data set for
understanding both your customers and
your content. And it's not just simple
number crunching like more likes means
better. The like button opens up an
exciting world of graph analytics that
I'm fairly certain most companies are
failing to take advantage of. Our guest
today is Bob Goodson, who in a stint as
a product manager at Yelp 20 years ago
was one of the inventors of the like
button. He's also the author of a book
about the history of the like button
called like the button that changed the
world. These days, Bob is president at
market intelligence company Quidd, where
he continues to help companies
understand their customers better. Have
a listen to this episode. I hope you
like it. when new things get developed,
especially when they're as successful as
something like the like button and now,
you know, emotional reaction buttons, uh
it's never one person, it's never one
company. It's always a a long string of
little tweaks and innovations that
culminate in something that's very
popular and successful. So, it's really
more of a process of evolution. We argue
that the like button paved the way and
conditioned people to get used to
reacting to content and that made it
much more likely that we would react to
an email or a text or a call. You know,
these these ways that companies can now
reach out and say, "How was that
experience?"
Hi Bob, welcome to the show. Hey Richie.
Wonderful. So uh just to begin with,
tell me how did the idea for the like
button come about? Well, it was 20 years
ago and May
2005, I was working as a product manager
in San Francisco for Yelp, US review
site. And we were, it's the early days
of Yelp and we were trying to figure out
how to make this feature that was called
send a compliment even more reactive and
quicker and easier to use uh because it
took a few page clicks, which at the
time if you wanted to give any kind of
feedback on the internet, that's what
was involved, believe it or not. And so
our co-founder Russ came over one day
and said,"I think I could use JavaScript
to keep people on the page." So when
they look at a business listing, they
could click multiple reviews and they
wouldn't leave the page to communicate
whether it was useful, funny, or cool.
And that would allow us to do more with
the reviews and show better reviews to
people um you know, near the top of the
page and and other useful things. So he
asked me to come up come up with a few
potential designs. One of which I put
the sketch in the book was the word like
in a thumbs up symbol which we actually
didn't use at Yelp. We uh we ended up uh
choosing useful, funny, cool as three
separate buttons without an icon. And we
became the first company to put multiple
emotions on a piece of web content and
the first to allow like a single click
without leaving the page to be able to
react to content. And we were just
trying to solve that day's design
problem. Um, we really only worked on it
for a day and um, and yeah, it kind of
went from there. But the book is all
about the fact that when new things get
developed, especially when they're as
successful as something like the like
button and now, you know, emotional
reaction buttons, uh, it's never one
person, it's never one company, it's
always a a long string of little tweaks
and innovations that culminate in
something that's very popular and
successful. So it's really more of a
process of evolution which is what we're
you know pointing to and trying to bring
light to in the book. That is very very
cool that it was just it was a one day
project just solving a a little thing
and this is now a ubiquitous feature of
just many many websites. So I'm always
curious is whenever something is just
everywhere you think okay well this is
an obvious solution to a problem but I
guess at the time it was brand new. It
wasn't obvious at all. So did he try
other things beyond just the idea of the
thumbs up? Like what else was tried
beyond uh what we now know as the like
button? Yeah, I mean even that day you
see from the notes we came up with
various ideas for how to present this
and how to interact with it. It really
wasn't an obvious choice. The thumb was
an obvious choice at the time. Neither
was the word like, you know, which is
why it's interesting that it was in the
notes. And um when we trace back the
origins of of other sites and you know
and we talked to founders like you know
we talk through this book we talked to
founders of of YouTube and LinkedIn and
um and Twitter and um you know I
recently interviewed the founder of
Pinterest and you know we talked to so
many people and around that time in the
sort of early 2000s so many things were
being used like the first icon on
YouTube was actually a heart symbol
which wasn't used much at all at the
time But when I spoke to Steve Chen, one
of the co-founders, he was saying that
they started with a heart partly because
YouTube started out as a dating site
actually only for two or three weeks. Uh
most people don't remember that era, but
uh they they thought it would be a good
place to add videos for dating purposes.
Uh but it didn't last very long and they
quickly realized there was a bigger, you
know, need and opportunity. But instead
of any kind of thumb or like they
actually had hearts on those videos,
that quickly got changed. friend feed,
which later got acquired by Facebook,
actually had just a little smiley face.
Even though they they were one of the
first to put the word like, well, they
were the first to put the word like on a
social media news feed, which has now
become a natural part of all social
networks, but in the time it wasn't. And
so, um, even for them, it with the word
like, it wasn't obvious that thumb would
go next to it. They had a smiley face.
And um so many different icons were
being tried and it it seems like the
thumb has some magical properties to it
that made it a very accepted icon in uh
in the west. Absolutely. That's
fascinating the way the idea just went
from one company to the next. I also
have no idea about YouTube originally
being a dating site. That's quite a
pivot really. Yeah. Okay. Uh so uh it's
interesting. So the thumbs kind of uh
won it. I guess you occasionally see
things like uh hearts as well. Do you
want to tell me a bit more about like
how the progression went then beyond
that like how did it take over the
world? It's been interesting for me to
to watch because on that day you know we
put these buttons on the content and
none of us thought that some something
important was happening. Um, you know, I
think everyone we spoke to, by the way,
that made important
uh contributions to the development of a
like button today have said the same
thing that they were solving that day's
design challenge and and the thing
evolves, right? And now there have been
many thousands of people that have
worked on this feature and many
different companies and so the the thing
that I've I noticed over the years is
that first of all, we didn't think too
much about it. Within a year or so, I
saw it start to spread to other sites. I
remember thinking really every few years
for the last 20 years I've witnessed
because I have a background in user
interface design I'm interested in these
things and all the apps I use I'm
curious like how they're evolving and I
would see this feature kind of gradually
spread and become more and more popular.
It was about 3 years after we did that
at Yelp that Facebook added uh the the
like button to its site. So, it even
took several years before it reached
Facebook, which most people think of as
sort of the the iconic um implementation
of that feature. And um yeah, and I
suppose I just kept thinking every few
years someone's going to write a book
about this or someone's going to write
like a an amazing wide article about
this feature and and I would look I
would search Google every few years and
look for that, you know, that thing and
no one's no one had written it, which
was really surprising. So, I ended up
chatting to a good friend of mine,
Martin Reeds, and we've written some
things before a few years ago, and uh I
mentioned this fact to him, and he was
so curious about the origin of the
button, he asked questions like you
have, like where did it come from or who
really did invent it? Um, and I couldn't
answer these questions. So, we started
pulling the thread. And as we researched
it, uh, we just found it a really
interesting keyhole. When you ask this
question, who invented the light button?
Where did it come from? you know, how
has it changed the way we interact
online? You actually uh uncover all
sorts of um new and deeper narratives
that have lessons, you know, broadly
when it comes to understanding tech, how
companies can innovate and um and what
it means for, you know, future waves of
technology as well. Lots of great
questions. I'm hoping we're going to get
some insight on some of those uh in the
rest of this episode. All right. So I
guess uh just from a technical point of
view it's like okay as a user of a
website you click like it's not
immediately obvious what happens next.
So when you click the button uh what
goes on behind the scenes. Yeah those of
you interested in data and analytics
will uh will will enjoy uh thinking
about and hearing about some of this.
First of all, before we get into, you
know, some of the interesting data that
flows from from likes, I would point out
that liking is and reacting to content
is what I describe as the atomic unit of
userenerated content. So, web 2.0 was
all about the era of userenerated
content. Essentially, the web went from
being something that around 10% of
people on the web would contribute or
create content. About 90% of users would

from anyone that's developing apps in
the early 2000s would look at their

know, they got all these visitors coming
and consuming content and very few
people actually creating the content
because the barrier to create it was
quite high. um there w wasn't really the
level of like trust in creating content
that there is now. I know there are
other types of tr trust issues but at
the time it was almost like a niche
activity to create content and almost
everyone was reading it. What web 2.0 OD
is it effectively brought 90% of people
that use the web into content creator
roles and now that number is probably
much higher and uh and so what companies

figure out ways to bring more people in
ways to engage people into content and
of course photos and uploading photos as
part of that uploading videos uh
commenting sharing forums all of these
are things that brought brought down the

simpler way to generate content than

They're merely trying to signal to

like you know they're expressing

a on a platform for example so it draws

was actually from like data. We can
think of that as the like graph, right?
It's it's the fact that you and I liked
or reacted to a piece of content. The
third wave that's come since we can
think of as the attention graph. the
fact that you know you and I like looked

or part of a graph. Um so the the the
latest wave of social media is is mostly
driven by that with the rise of Tik Tok
which is really the main graph they care
about the only graph they they seem to
care about uh is the the uh you know the
attention and what that tells them about
what other people would want to see.
That's absolutely fascinating. And yeah,
I hadn't really thought of the like um
button being around the same time as all

okay, you can write uh encyclopedia

Yeah, that's a good question because we
have to ask ourselves with something

7 billion times a day. We we estimate
there are more than seven billion

on on you know in the browser. That's a

why is it so successful? You know what

None. None of you have checked the

incredibly intuitive and it's something
that is is so widely used and and there
are there are a couple of elements. We
we talk about this at length in the

uh neuroscientists and psychologists as
well uh to inform our perspective on
this. And what we took away two two main
things we took away is that it uh is a
powerful way to um uh connect with the
dopamine response. So you know there
there is a sort of anticipation element
of will I get likes for this and then
there's a reward element that you do get
likes. Uh similarly when you when you
give likes there's there's kind of a a
hit involved in that as well. So there's
m much has been said about dopamine and
social media in general and certainly
liking ties into that. The other is
around social the fact that humans are
fundamentally uh wired for social
learning. We learn from those around us.
We want to surround ourselves with
people we can learn from and um and and
we we have a we we have a craving for a
sort of mild hierarchy as humans. We we
don't have such um attraction to sort of
stark hierarchy. Um you know we we like
a certain amount of freedom and space
but we are drawn to a what we describe
as sort of mild hierarchy. We want to be
around people that we think are slightly
cooler than us and um slightly smarter
than us or slightly more attractive than
us. And so we have that interest in and
so we need ways to kind of level up with
those around us. And social media
provides an effective way to do that.
And liking is a sort of currency of
interaction in that type of um in that
type of what we describe as sort of
learning sociality. And so those are a
couple of things that humans are very
very hardwired for that people are
hardwired for. And we um uh and the like
button seems to tap into both of those
in a in a pretty smooth and and
elemental way. Okay. Yeah. I suppose it
makes sense that something that's going
to be successful has to kind of align

or cultural preferences. And I suppose
there's a a politeness angle here as
well. It's like someone creates some
great content and just claim like is a
is a very simple way to say thank you.
Yeah, exactly. There's there's certainly
um a reciprocation or a gratitude, you

right. Super. So uh that's kind of uh
the uh one of the mechanism for like

right you go for a coffee and you get an

I can see your review, Richie, now. So,
I think but if you if you think if you

that's really interesting. Um from
